item.title: Already know the Big Dipper? There's more to this group of stars
item.content:encoded: Most of us can spot the group of stars known as the Plough or the Big Dipper. But there’s more to explore here, says Abigail Beall

item.title: The bold attempt to solve the toughest mystery at the heart of physics
item.content:encoded: Finding out whether gravity – and therefore space-time itself – is quantum in nature has long been thought impossible. But innovative new ideas might be about to help answer this crucial question

item.title: Joshua Oppenheimer's The End is a superb musical set in the end times
item.content:encoded: In a luxury survival bunker, a rich family lie to each other as Earth's surface becomes unviable. But things change when a young woman stumbles on them in The End, a wonderful, end-of-the-world musical drama, says Simon Ings

item.title: The wild idea that we all get nutrients from the air that we breathe
item.content:encoded: Growing evidence suggests a source of nutrition might be right under our noses. But how important are such aeronutrients – and can we harness them to better treat deficiencies?

item.title: US East Coast faces rising seas as crucial Atlantic current slows
item.content:encoded: The weakening of the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) is boosting the sea level along the New England coast on top of sea level rise from melting ice, adding to flooding

item.title: Babies start showing empathy even before they can speak
item.content:encoded: When adults pretended to be in pain, children as young as 9 months old comforted them, pushing back the earliest age when humans are known to display empathy

item.title: The most – and least – satisfying jobs out there, according to science
item.content:encoded: Some jobs are more satisfying than others, and they're not necessarily the ones with a high income or a lot of prestige

item.title: Baby with rare disease given world-first personal CRISPR gene therapy
item.content:encoded: An infant with a severe genetic condition has shown signs of improvement after receiving a gene-editing treatment tailored to his specific mutation

item.title: Toxic waste is spilling onto beaches as rising seas erode landfills
item.content:encoded: Waste from old landfill sites is spilling onto beaches as rising seas erode coastlines - and some of it is toxic

item.title: Could a $125 billion investment fund halt global deforestation?
item.content:encoded: The Tropical Forests Forever Facility, an initiative spearheaded by Brazil, would raise money from investments and pay countries to preserve forests – can it succeed where carbon markets have failed?

item.title: What the complete ape genome is revealing about the earliest humans
item.content:encoded: We now have full genome sequences for six species of apes, helping us to pin down our last common ancestor – and potentially changing how we think of the earliest hominins

item.title: Risk of a star destroying the solar system is higher than expected
item.content:encoded: Stars that pass close to the solar system could pull planets out of alignment, sending them hurtling into the sun or out into space

item.title: An interview with Larry Niven – Ringworld author and sci-fi legend
item.content:encoded: The author of Ringworld, the latest read for the New Scientist Book Club, is quizzed on everything from if he’d like to meet an alien to the art of writing

item.title: Remarkable photos highlight the haunting resilience of nature
item.content:encoded: Acclaimed photographers Paul Nicklen and Cristina Mittermeier showcase a changing planet as part of the Photo London photography fair

item.title: Grisly new book reveals what zombie insects can teach us
item.content:encoded: In Rise of the Zombie Bugs, Mindy Weisberger zooms in on how parasites hijack the brains of their tiny host animals

item.title: Are entangled qubits following a quantum Moore's law?
item.content:encoded: Several recent experiments showcase a sharp increase in the number of quantum bits that can be entangled, echoing Moore’s law for increasing computing power on traditional chips

item.title: Robert Macfarlane is wrong to cast rivers as life forms in new book
item.content:encoded: We should protect Earth's rivers and forests with laws. But it is another matter to claim them as living beings, as Robert Macfarlane does in his new book Is a River Alive?

item.title: Physicists reveal the secret to chopping onions without crying
item.content:encoded: Slicing an onion releases tear-inducing chemicals into the air, but the sharpness of the knife and the speed of the cut can affect how these droplets are expelled

item.title: How dark energy findings may inspire a new generation of physics nerds
item.content:encoded: The discovery of the cosmic acceleration problem truly inspired me as a teenage physics nerd. Recent, related revelations about dark energy will hopefully capture the interest of today’s young science geeks, says Chanda Prescod-Weinstein

item.title: Who needs Eurovision when we have the Dance Your PhD contest?
item.content:encoded: As Eurovision looms, Feedback enjoys discovering more about the winners of this year's Dance Your PhD contest, who have an original take on chemesthesis, the sense that detects the heat of chillies and the coolness of menthol

item.title: Promises to improve nature are being broken by English house builders
item.content:encoded: In spite of policies requiring housing projects in England to benefit nature, many of the trees, habitats and nest boxes included in planning applications haven't materialised

item.title: When it comes to crime, you can't algorithm your way to safety
item.content:encoded: There are serious issues with new proposals to use artificial intelligence to predict future crimes, says Yu Xiong, chair of the advisory board to the UK's All-Party Parliamentary Group on the Metaverse and Web 3.0

item.title: A doe-eyed look at space exploration is inadequate for the zeitgeist
item.content:encoded: In highly politicised times, is living off-world something we should entertain, let alone do? Adriana Marais's futurist dream Out of This World and Into the Next feels tone deaf

item.title: China's CO2 emissions have started falling – is this finally the peak?
item.content:encoded: For the first time ever, China’s carbon dioxide emissions have declined even as its power demand has increased, a possible sign of a longer-term fall in emissions

item.title: Norovirus vaccine pill protects against winter vomiting bug
item.content:encoded: An oral vaccine reduced infection risk in a trial where people were deliberately exposed to high doses of norovirus, and could also slow the spread of the pathogen

item.title: Exquisite new-to-science frog species has golden legs and odd habits
item.content:encoded: A newly described poison dart frog, which is about the size of a thumbnail, has been found in the forests of the Juruá river basin in Brazil

item.title: Are democratic countries like the UK just climate hypocrites?
item.content:encoded: New research suggests wealthy democracies offshore their pollution to other nations – but is that what’s really going on?

item.title: The complexity of female sex hormones calls for more science, not less
item.content:encoded: Women were historically excluded from health studies on the grounds that hormone fluctuations introduced "noise" into the data, and this has left us with a lack of understanding about a range of conditions

item.title: One half of the moon is hotter than the other
item.content:encoded: Anomalies in the moon’s gravitational field suggest our satellite’s insides are warmer on one side than the other – which means that its interior is asymmetric

item.title: Fossil tracks rewrite history of animals leaving water to live on land
item.content:encoded: The footprints of a reptile-like creature appear to have been laid down around 356 million years ago, pushing back the earliest known instance of animals emerging from the water to live on land

item.title: Surprising insights into the causes of PMDD promise better treatments
item.content:encoded: Premenstrual dysphoric disorder can cause monthly cycles of rage, depression, anxiety and self-harm. Treatments are limited, but new ideas about the condition could change that

item.title: Earth is heading for a second year above 1.5°C climate goal
item.content:encoded: After record temperatures in 2024, climate scientists had expected this year to be cooler, but instead the planet seems to be heading for a second year above the 1.5°C climate goal

item.title: Chemists discover 'anti-spice' that could make chilli peppers less hot
item.content:encoded: An analysis of compounds in chilli peppers has revealed chemicals that seem to negate their heat-giving capsaicinoids. This explains why the Scoville scale for measuring spicyness isn't always accurate, and could eventually lead to the development of an "anti-spice" condiment

item.title: Smart device can measure how much milk breastfed babies really drink
item.content:encoded: Not knowing how much milk a baby consumes when breastfeeding can cause anxiety for parents, but an innovative device seems to provide objective measurements

item.title: Radical photon idea could rewrite standard model of particle physics
item.content:encoded: Experiments with hydrogen atoms could soon reveal whether particles that were long thought to be forbidden by physics actually do exist

item.title: The FBI is getting new technology to see through walls
item.content:encoded: A lunchbox-sized radar system could help the FBI detect moving or stationary people by peering through walls via radio waves

item.title: Massive wildfires in Canada helped keep the world cooler in 2023
item.content:encoded: Despite setting a global temperature record, 2023 might have been even hotter were it not for the cooling effect of smoke from massive wildfires in Canada

item.title: Parkinson's disease could be detected by listening to someone's voice
item.content:encoded: The pitch and hoarseness of a person's voice often changes if they have Parkinson's disease, suggesting there could be a non-invasive way of screening for the condition

item.title: Migraine drug that treats headache also eases symptoms like dizziness
item.content:encoded: The drug ubrogepant doesn't just ease the headache of a migraine, but also relieves symptoms like neck stiffness and fatigue if taken early enough

item.title: Go-to migraine drug actually does nothing to relieve vertigo symptoms
item.content:encoded: The drug rizatriptan is often recommended for vestibular migraines, which cause vertigo as well as headache, but doesn't actually seem to be effective

item.title: How ancient humans survived a global climate disaster 8200 years ago
item.content:encoded: Plummeting temperatures forced some human populations to adapt to the new conditions thousands of years ago, but the changes they made varied widely

item.title: Alien megastructures would likely self-destruct before we spot them
item.content:encoded: Dyson spheres, a type of huge megastructure designed to capture the energy output of a star, would be a sign of an alien civilisation – if we can find one before they disappear

item.title: New way to pull uranium from water can help China's nuclear power push
item.content:encoded: Chinese researchers have a new method to extract uranium from seawater twice as cheaply as previous technologies. Their success comes as China needs uranium to fuel its unprecedented nuclear expansion

item.title: All living things emit an eerie glow that is snuffed out upon death
item.content:encoded: Our bodies emit a stream of low-energy photons, and now experiments in mice have revealed that this ghostly glow is cut off when we die

item.title: What are microplastics doing to your brain? We’re starting to find out
item.content:encoded: The average human brain contains around 7 grams of plastic, but it’s unclear how this affects us. Now animal studies are revealing links to poor cognition and weird behaviour

item.title: Why physicists keep trying to get rid of space-time entirely
item.content:encoded: Physicists are trying to ditch the concept of space-time – the supposed fabric of physical reality. Quantum columnist Karmela Padavic-Callaghan explains why

item.title: Can we get better at spotting when someone is lying?
item.content:encoded: A reader wonders if they can become less gullible. Our science-based advice columnist David Robson has some surprising answers

item.title: What 7 fiendishly hard puzzles tell us about the nature of mathematics
item.content:encoded: 25 years ago, a $1 million reward was promised to anyone who could solve one of seven incredibly hard maths riddles. With only one of them now solved, what will it take to crack the rest?

item.title: Nothing is stronger than quantum connections – and now we know why
item.content:encoded: The mathematics of graphs has helped reveal a principle that limits the strength of quantum correlations – and explains why physicists have never measured any stronger connections in some post-quantum realm

item.title: How to harness your emotions for a happier, calmer life
item.content:encoded: From anger to envy, research is revealing how to shift your mental state and put bad feelings to good use – with benefits for longevity, relationships and mental health

item.title: Climate drama Families Like Ours deserves to be a word-of-mouth hit
item.content:encoded: A disturbing new Danish TV series, which follows a wealthy family as rising seas force the evacuation of Denmark, is wildly popular in its home country. We should all be watching it, says Bethan Ackerley

item.title: Does intermittent fasting improve gut health? Why it’s hard to say
item.content:encoded: While intermittent fasting may be growing in popularity, relatively little is known about how it impacts our gut microbiome – for better or for worse

item.title: AI hallucinations are getting worse – and they're here to stay
item.content:encoded: An AI leaderboard suggests the newest reasoning models used in chatbots are producing less accurate results because of higher hallucination rates. Experts say the problem is bigger than that

item.title: The everyday ways climate change is already making our lives worse
item.content:encoded: Extreme weather events are the most dramatic consequence of climate change, but there are many smaller ways it disturbs our daily life

item.title: Was a famous supernova an alien invader from another galaxy?
item.content:encoded: Kepler's Supernova, seen in 1604, is one of the most famous exploding stars ever seen, and now astronomers think it may have been an interloper from another galaxy

item.title: Chimps share 'building blocks of musical rhythm' with humans
item.content:encoded: Just like humans, chimps have rhythm when drumming, which suggests that the trait evolved in our common ancestor

item.title: Major US cities like New York and Seattle are sinking at a rapid rate
item.content:encoded: Groundwater extraction, plate tectonics and consequences of the last glacial period mean that most of the US's biggest cities are sinking

item.title: Is the fungal science in The Last of Us going off the rails?
item.content:encoded: With season 2 unfolding, the science of the fungal horror drama is becoming shakier. It is a pity that the creators haven’t thought about terrifying scenarios of real-life infection, says Corrado Nai

item.title: Our favourite science fiction books of all time (the ones we forgot)
item.content:encoded: Following on from our first list, we asked New Scientist staff to pick even more of their favourite sci-fi books of all time. From Isaac Asimov and Ursula K. Le Guin to Star Wars – the list has it all this time, we hope…

item.title: Europe increasingly vulnerable to hailstones the size of golfballs
item.content:encoded: Very large hail – hailstones more than 5 centimetres in diameter – poses a growing threat to Europe as the climate warms, with increasing risk of expensive damage to cars and property

item.title: These photos reveal the unique agricultural system of the Maya people
item.content:encoded: Combining sustainability, climate resilience and environmental preservation, the ancient “milpa” system of the Maya revealed in these images has been practiced for millennia

item.title: Marcus du Sautoy's new book is good on maths, less so on the arts
item.content:encoded: The mathematician is out to show the close link between maths and the arts. This idea isn't new, and while Blueprints is lyrical on maths, it falls a bit flat when it comes to covering artists

item.title: Failed Soviet probe will soon crash to Earth – and we don't know where
item.content:encoded: Kosmos 482, a Soviet spacecraft that never made it beyond Earth’s orbit on its way to Venus, is due to come crashing down on 9 or 10 May

item.title: The maths that tells us when a scientific discovery is real – or not
item.content:encoded: When huge scientific discoveries are made, you may hear that they are “statistically significant” or pass a threshold called “5 sigma” – but those calculations can be manipulated to make claims seem grander than they are, finds Jacob Aron

item.title: Record heat in 2023 and 2024 may just have been natural variability
item.content:encoded: Simulations suggest that an extraordinary jump in temperatures seen in 2023 and 2024 could simply be natural variability, rather than a new phase of climate change as some researchers have suggested

item.title: What if we could experience life as another species?
item.content:encoded: In this latest instalment of our speculative column Future Chronicles, an imagined history of future inventions, Rowan Hooper explores the pros (and cons) of networking our brains with those of other animals

item.title: The birds upending our idea of shared parenting
item.content:encoded: Superb starlings appear to swap between parent and ‘nanny’ roles to help raise chicks over their lifetimes, even when they aren’t related to them

item.title: Quantum computers could protect our data from quantum computers
item.content:encoded: A powerful enough quantum computer could crack the encryption methods currently used to protect data around the world, but the solution might be a quantum algorithm once thought to be completely useless

item.title: Would snails be better than whales for explaining big data? Maybe
item.content:encoded: Feedback's proposal that the genome of the blue whale could be used to communicate the scale of large datasets is knocked back by a reader with a radical alternative suggestion

item.title: Don't ban kids from social media; create a site that works for them
item.content:encoded: Rather than simply keeping children away from social media, we need a specially designed option for them. This is how it should look, says Michael Marshall

item.title: An expert's new book unravels the amazing secrets of the vagus nerve
item.content:encoded: Kevin Tracey's authoritative look at the vagus nerve and its healing potential is comprehensive and compelling, cutting through the hype

item.title: Dementia cases are rising faster in China than the rest of the world
item.content:encoded: Cases of dementia doubled worldwide between 1990 and 2021, but more than quadrupled in China during the same period

item.title: 99.999 per cent of the deep seabed remains unexplored by humans
item.content:encoded: Deep-sea submersibles have been diving for decades, but records show that we have still only explored a tiny area of the deep seabed, which makes up the majority of Earth's topography

item.title: Science is a Pandora's box – but we should open it anyway
item.content:encoded: We are often warned of the consequences of knowing too much, but even when scientific ideas have the potential to be harmful we should still seek to understand them

item.title: Strange microbes give clues to the ancestor of all complex life
item.content:encoded: The origin of complex eukaryotic cells, of the type found in all plants and animals, is shrouded in mystery. Now, strange microbes from wetlands in China are helping us to understand when they first emerged, and what they were like

item.title: Concerns raised over AI trained on 57 million NHS medical records
item.content:encoded: The makers of an AI model called Foresight say it could help predict disease or hospitalisation rates, but others have expressed concern about the fact it is trained on millions of health records

item.title: England has just given the thumbs up to gene-edited plants. Hooray!
item.content:encoded: A UK parliamentary committee has greenlit gene-edited plants. This is great news, as it will boost food production and reduce waste, says Michael Le Page

item.title: A clean energy source may be lurking beneath mountain ranges
item.content:encoded: As the search for geologic hydrogen - a potential clean source of energy beneath the ground - continues, some researchers are turning to mountains

item.title: Chronic pain could be eased by learning to regulate negative emotions
item.content:encoded: An adaptation of cognitive behavioural therapy that focuses on mindfulness and tolerating distress has shown promise for relieving chronic pain

item.title: Landslide rescuers to get help from rapid analysis of seismic data
item.content:encoded: Being able to quickly pinpoint the location of events such as landslides and pyroclastic flows will help rescue efforts, say the team behind a new technique for doing so

item.title: Ireland's iconic megalithic tombs may have had an unexpected function
item.content:encoded: Tombs that are scattered across Ireland may have helped bring ancient societies together for feasting and remembering their ancestors

item.title: Shingles vaccine linked with lower risk of many common heart problems
item.content:encoded: Shingles is associated with an increased chance of health problems like strokes and heart attacks, but receiving a shingles jab seems to curb the risk of such cardiovascular problems

item.title: US government is using AI for unprecedented social media surveillance
item.content:encoded: Under the Trump administration, multiple US government agencies are using AI and other tools to broadly track the social media of tourists and immigrants – and potentially to watch US citizens as well

item.title: Psychedelics may boost mental health by dampening inflammation
item.content:encoded: Psychedelic drugs like MDMA and psilocybin may help treat depression, anxiety and other mental health conditions by reducing the number of inflammatory cells around the brain

item.title: Quantum computers don’t always need more qubits – just add chaos
item.content:encoded: To create useful randomness in a quantum computer, you could add more quantum bits, but using quantum chaos does the trick too

item.title: Can running too far be bad for your health?
item.content:encoded: There’s no doubt that doing some long-distance running improves our fitness, but at what point does it become too much, asks Grace Wade

item.title: Drugs like Wegovy can be effective at treating fatty liver disease
item.content:encoded: Semaglutide, a drug commonly taken for weight loss, showed marked benefits for most patients in a trial for metabolic dysfunction-associated steatohepatitis (MASH)

item.title: How vanishing Y chromosomes could help explain men's ill health
item.content:encoded: The enigmatic Y chromosome has a tendency to disappear from cells with age. Now, research is revealing the long-term impacts this can have on disease risk and life expectancy

item.title: How a simple walk can bust stress, boost cognition and fight diseases
item.content:encoded: We all know that walking is good for us, but growing evidence reveals that the right hike can exponentially enhance the health benefits

item.title: The 'impossible' particle hinting at the universe's biggest secrets
item.content:encoded: Neutrinos have always been hard to explain – and now the detection of one so energetic it shouldn't exist may help illuminate the strangest corners of the cosmos

item.title: The world, the universe and us: We're relaunching our weekly podcast
item.content:encoded: After 300 episodes of New Scientist Weekly, it's time for a refresh. Our flagship podcast has a new name but remains a show that can restore optimism and nourish your brain

item.title: This sensational novel shows what climate fiction can be
item.content:encoded: It can be difficult to work out which books count as climate fiction. Emily H. Wilson reads the shortlist for the Climate Fiction prize – and discovers Roz Dineen's powerful novel Briefly Very Beautiful

item.title: Bitter argument breaks out over controversial theory of consciousness
item.content:encoded: Research aiming to answer the great mystery of how consciousness arises is continuing to spark debate, with arguments over whether one leading idea – integrated information theory – even counts as science

item.title: Disastrous back-to-back heatwaves and droughts surge across Eurasia
item.content:encoded: Regions from Ukraine to Mongolia are seeing a spike in paired heatwave-drought events as climate change alters weather patterns across the planet

item.title: Tiny rewards can protect the grid from a surge in electric vehicles
item.content:encoded: As the number of electric vehicles increases, their increased demand could strain the grid – but small financial incentives convinced drivers to ease that demand by charging during off-peak hours

item.title: Dark energy bombshell sparks race to find a new model of the universe
item.content:encoded: ‘Shocking’ results from a major astronomical study have raised doubts about the standard model of cosmology, forcing scientists to consider new ways of understanding dark energy and gravity

item.title: Innovative antivenom may work against the world's deadliest snakes
item.content:encoded: Scientists have created an antivenom that has shown promise against some of the world's deadliest snakes after collecting antibodies from a hyperimmune man who exposed himself to their toxins

item.title: Extreme heat poses Spanish-style blackout threat to UK electrical grid
item.content:encoded: As climate change pushes summer temperatures to new highs, energy infrastructure such as cabling and transformers will struggle to cope

item.title: Brain signals can change the gut microbiome in as little as 2 hours
item.content:encoded: We have known for years that the gut microbiome can alter brain function, but now research in mice is suggesting that the opposite is also true – that the brain modifies gut bacteria

item.title: Best evidence yet that dolphin whistles are like a shared language
item.content:encoded: While dolphins are known to transmit information in their whistles, until now it hasn't been clear whether the marine mammals used the same sounds to indicate a shared understanding of a concept
